statement.text: Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) is fibrotic hardening of the skin and subcutaneous tissue in the gaiter area of the lower leg from chronic venous hypertension, creating the classic 'inverted champagne bottle' deformity and signifying advanced chronic venous disease (CEAP C4b).
statement.formal: LDS: Chronic_Venous_HTN → Fibrosis + Fat_Necrosis → Skin_Hardening + Contracture

explanation.intuition: Years of venous pressure backing up into the skin causes inflammation and scarring of the fat and tissue under the skin. The ankle area shrinks and hardens while the calf above stays normal - looking like an upside-down champagne bottle.
explanation.key_insight: LDS represents significant end-organ damage from venous hypertension. The acute phase (painful, red, warm) can mimic cellulitis. Chronic LDS is irreversible fibrosis. Both phases represent C4b disease and high ulceration risk.
explanation.technical_details: Pathophysiology: venous hypertension → leukocyte trapping → inflammation → fibrin cuff → fat necrosis → fibrosis. Location: gaiter area (lower third of leg). Phases: acute (painful panniculitis, mimics cellulitis) and chronic (painless, woody, contracted). CEAP: C4b. Treatment: compression (prevents progression), treat reflux, pentoxifylline may help acute phase. Prognosis: high risk of ulceration (C6).

clinical_features.appearance: Hardened, contracted skin with 'inverted champagne bottle' shape
clinical_features.pathophysiology: Fibrin cuff formation, fat necrosis, subcutaneous fibrosis

primary_sources.title: Handbook of Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

clinical_pearls: Acute LDS can mimic cellulitis - key difference is bilateral and location
'Inverted champagne bottle' is classic appearance of chronic LDS
Indicates high risk for venous ulceration without treatment
